messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 22, 2017 - November 28, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-29T20:34:52Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-11-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171129-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-11-25T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2017-11-28T00:00Z-03:00Z. The second slight enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2017-11-27.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~490 km/s on 2017-11-27.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-11-24 with the solar wind speed reaching values of >600 km/s. 


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been very low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-11-23T07:48Z     ~505            C               -90/30                13                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-12-05T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week. There are several decayed active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Some increase in geomagnetic activity is expected due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-11-30 originating from the northern extension of the southern polar coronal hole seen in SDO images.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-25T20:28:26Z
## Message ID: 20171125-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-11-25T06:54Z.

Estimated speed: ~424 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -42/15 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-11-25T06:54:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME would reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2017-11-29T10:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2017-11-25T06:54:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171125_150200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 15, 2017 - November 21, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-22T20:43:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-11-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171122-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-11-21T03:00Z to 2017-11-21T09:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-20. The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2017-11-21.  Another small coronal hole high speed stream was detected earlier by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-15 where the solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2017-11-16. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-11-17.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2017-11-18.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  


## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-11-28T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are still several decayed active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt may increase in the next few days due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-20.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 08, 2017 - November 14, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-15T21:33:42Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-11-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171115-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period, there were no significant flares.  An S-type (<500 km/s) CME was detected on the SOHO coronagraph imagery at 2017-11-10T08:00Z.  This CME arrival was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-14T00:51Z.  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=6 started during the previous reporting period at 2017-11-07T18:00Z and lasted to the synoptic period ending at 2017-11-08T06:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-07. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-11-12 with the solar wind speed reaching values of 400-450 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-11-09T15:50Z and remained elevated crossing the threshold several times up to 2017-11-13. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20171109-AL-001, 20171109-AL-002, 20171111-AL-001 and 20171113-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed            


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  


## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-11-21T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  Active regions on the solar disk have decayed with a low probability of major flares or fast CMEs. Some increase in geomagnetic activity is expected due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-11-15 originating from the southern extension of the northern polar coronal hole seen in SDO.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-13T13:30:28Z
## Message ID: 20171113-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to notification with ID 20171111-AL-001. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. The GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu on 2017-11-09T15:50Z and continues to be above this threshold, currently at 125,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2017-11-07T01:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-11-09T15:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )

##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-09T16:15:13Z
## Message ID: 20171109-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-11-09T15:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-11-07T01:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-11-09T15:50:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-09T16:03:18Z
## Message ID: 20171109-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-11-09T15:50Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-11-09T15:50:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 01, 2017 - November 07, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-08T19:51:49Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-11-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171108-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There were no major solar flares or CMEs.   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest values of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-11-07T18:00 to 2017-11-08T06:00Z.  This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-11-07 (see notifications 20171107-AL-001 and 20171107-AL-002). The solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-11-07.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-11-14T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are a couple of active regions present on the far side of the Sun as seen from the STEREO A EUVI images that can potentially produce some solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be elevated for the next few days due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  Currently, the solar wind speed detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 reached values of >650 km/s.   

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-07T22:00:27Z
## Message ID: 20171107-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-11-07T18:00Z to 2017-11-07T21:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-11-07T01:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-11-07T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 25, 2017 - October 31, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-11-01T23:05:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-10-31T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171101-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.


Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-10-25T06:00Z-09:00Z. This slight enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 the week before around 2017-10-24 with solar wind speed reaching values of ~600 km/s. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-10-28 with the solar wind speed reaching values of 600-700 km/s.  
   

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been very low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-11-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-11-07T23:59Z

Solar and geomagnetic activity are expected to be low for the upcoming week. All three active regions currently visible at the solar surface are in their decaying phase and have not shown any major activity in the last days and there is only a slight chance of flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity may increase in the next couple of days due to a high speed stream originating from a small southern low-latitude coronal hole seen in SDO near central meridian on 2017-10-29.



## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
